test_cases.description: Patient with documented infection risks post-surgery.
test_cases.patient_payload: A 15-year-old female presented for surgical correction of idiopathic scoliosis. Post-operatively, her surgical site revealed erythema and purulent drainage. Despite appropriate antibiotic prophylaxis administered within 60 minutes, a wound culture returned positive for MRSA. The team recognized that prolonged operative time exceeded 4 hours without adequate redosing. Discharge instructions were unclear regarding signs of infection, leading to a 15-day post-op admission for surgical site infection. Neurovascular exam was documented pre-op but lacked post-op details. The patient's clinical stability was compromised due to infection risks, emphasizing the necessity for improved discharge education and timely antibiotic management.

must_find_signals: Wound culture returned positive for MRSA
Prolonged operative time exceeded 4 hours without adequate redosing

must_contain_phrases: neurovascular exam was documented pre-op but lacked post-op details

test_cases.description: Patient with documented bundle compliance but complications arose.
test_cases.patient_payload: An 18-year-old male underwent posterior spinal fusion for idiopathic scoliosis. Pre-operatively, the patient was warmed, and chlorhexidine prep was documented. However, antibiotic redosing was missed due to excessive traffic in the OR during a prolonged procedure lasting over 5 hours. Post-operative, the patient experienced uncontrolled pain and required readmission for hardware-related issues that could have been mitigated by adherence to the DVT prophylaxis protocol. Documentation showed that the surgical pause was performed, yet the timing for antibiotic dosing was not documented, highlighting a gap in compliance with best practices for surgical care.

must_find_signals: excessive traffic in the OR during a prolonged procedure
documentation showed that the surgical pause was performed

must_contain_phrases: gaps in compliance with best practices for surgical care

test_cases.description: Unplanned admission due to missing outcome risks.
test_cases.patient_payload: A 15-year-old female patient with adolescent idiopathic scoliosis underwent spinal fusion surgery. Post-operatively, there was no documentation of neurovascular status or perfusion checks. Three days post-discharge, she presented to the ER with signs of infection and loss of reduction requiring re-operation. The absence of a neurovascular exam and failure to monitor for infection contributed to her unplanned admission. Her condition was exacerbated by the lack of clear discharge instructions and inadequate follow-up planning.

test_cases.description: Unplanned admission due to missing readmission risks.
test_cases.patient_payload: A 17-year-old male with adolescent idiopathic scoliosis had spinal instrumentation and fusion. After discharge, he developed uncontrolled pain and gastrointestinal complications that were not addressed before discharge. The surgical team failed to document pain management plans and bowel regimen recommendations. He returned to the OR within two weeks due to severe abdominal distension and a suspected ileus. This readmission could have been prevented with better preoperative education and pain control measures.

must_find_signals: failure to document pain management plans

test_cases.description: Review of SSI prevention bundle documentation for AIS fusion.
test_cases.patient_payload: A 15-year-old female underwent anterior instrumentation and fusion for idiopathic scoliosis. On post-operative day 3, she displayed signs of infection with fever and purulent drainage at the surgical site. Review of the surgical notes revealed that the full SSI prevention bundle was not documented. Specifically, the timing of antibiotic prophylaxis was unclear and there was no record of chlorhexidine prep used prior to incision. These omissions raise concerns regarding adherence to the SSI prevention bundle and highlight potential gaps in perioperative care.

must_find_signals: the full SSI prevention bundle was not documented
timing of antibiotic prophylaxis was unclear
no record of chlorhexidine prep used prior to incision

test_cases.description: Categorization of readmission reason after AIS surgery.
test_cases.patient_payload: A 17-year-old male was readmitted on post-operative day 10 after AIS fusion due to severe abdominal pain and nausea. Upon review, it was determined that he had developed an ileus, but the reason for readmission was not clearly documented in the medical records. The surgical report only mentioned 'complications' without specifying infection, GI issues, hardware concerns, or pain. This lack of clarity in categorization complicates the assessment of the readmission and hampers prevention efforts for future cases.

must_find_signals: the reason for readmission was not clearly documented

test_cases.description: Return to OR for hardware revision documented as unplanned.
test_cases.patient_payload: A 15-year-old female with idiopathic scoliosis underwent posterior spinal fusion. Post-operative day 3, she experienced unexpected pain out of proportion to her recovery, and a neurological deficit was noted with paresthesia in her left leg. Imaging revealed hardware failure, resulting in an unplanned return to the OR for revision. The documentation ambiguously indicated whether this return was planned or unplanned, leading to confusion about the event's preventability. Discharge instructions were also unclear regarding signs of complications, contributing to the unplanned admission.

must_find_signals: pain out of proportion to recovery
documentation ambiguously indicated whether this return was planned or unplanned

must_contain_phrases: return to the OR for revision

test_cases.description: Discharge instructions and follow-up appointments poorly documented.
test_cases.patient_payload: An 18-year-old male with adolescent idiopathic scoliosis underwent anterior spinal fusion. He was discharged on post-operative day 2 but the discharge instructions were vaguely documented, lacking clarity on follow-up appointments and signs of potential complications. After experiencing gastrointestinal complications, he was readmitted within 10 days. The ambiguity in the discharge instructions contributed to his unplanned admission, as the patient did not recognize the severity of his symptoms due to unclear guidance.

must_find_signals: lack of clarity on follow-up appointments
ambiguity in the discharge instructions contributed to his unplanned admission

test_cases.description: Patient with documented infection risks during surgery.
test_cases.patient_payload: A 16-year-old female diagnosed with idiopathic scoliosis underwent corrective surgery. Preoperatively, she was given appropriate antibiotic prophylaxis within 60 minutes of incision, and her surgical site was meticulously prepared with chlorhexidine. Intraoperatively, the surgical team noted no signs of infection and performed a thorough wound inspection. Postoperative care included monitoring for infection, with all relevant documentation confirming no evidence of prolonged operative time or inappropriate antibiotic selection. Discharge instructions clearly outlined signs of infection to monitor.

must_find_signals: Antibiotic prophylaxis not given within 60 min

must_contain_phrases: antibiotic prophylaxis not given within 60 min

test_cases.description: Patient with documented bundle compliance during surgery.
test_cases.patient_payload: An 18-year-old male with adolescent idiopathic scoliosis was admitted for spinal fusion surgery. All preoperative warming protocols were documented, and the surgical timeout was completed without discrepancies. The surgical team confirmed antibiotic redosing in line with the prolonged operative time. There was strict adherence to the post-op dressing protocol, and DVT prophylaxis was initiated as per guidelines. Discharge instructions were explicit regarding follow-up care and signs of complications, ensuring comprehensive education was provided.

must_find_signals: Antibiotic redosing missed in long case

must_contain_phrases: Antibiotic redosing missed in long case

test_cases.description: Clear documentation of outcome risks post-surgery.
test_cases.patient_payload: A 15-year-old female with idiopathic scoliosis underwent posterior spinal fusion. Post-operatively, she exhibited signs of compartment syndrome with pain out of proportion to injury, and her neurovascular exam documented pallor and delayed capillary refill. The surgical team noted the need for fasciotomy due to increasing tension in the compartment and unexpected ICU admission for monitoring. All documentation was thorough, capturing the perfusion status as pink and warm pre-op and post-op, ensuring no gaps in the neurovascular assessment. The case highlights the importance of monitoring and timely intervention to prevent complications.

must_find_signals: pain out of proportion to injury

test_cases.description: Clear documentation of readmission risks post-surgery.
test_cases.patient_payload: A 17-year-old male with adolescent idiopathic scoliosis was discharged after spinal fusion surgery. He returned to the ER within 10 days due to uncontrolled pain, and the surgical site was found to be infected, indicating a surgical site infection (SSI). Documentation indicated that antibiotic prophylaxis was not administered within 60 minutes of incision, and the patient had a history of prior infection. The case underlines the critical need for strict adherence to infection control protocols and thorough discharge instructions to prevent readmissions.

must_find_signals: antibiotic prophylaxis not given within 60 min

test_cases.description: Patient readmitted due to surgical site infection after scoliosis surgery.
test_cases.patient_payload: A 15-year-old female with idiopathic scoliosis underwent posterior spinal fusion. Despite the operation being performed without antibiotic prophylaxis within 60 minutes, she was discharged with vague instructions. One week post-discharge, she presented with erythema and purulent drainage at the surgical site. The absence of proper documentation regarding antibiotic timing and the patient's clear discharge instructions contributed to her readmission for surgical site infection management.

must_find_signals: Antibiotic prophylaxis not given within 60 min

test_cases.description: Patient readmitted due to complications from missed bundle compliance.
test_cases.patient_payload: A 17-year-old male with adolescent idiopathic scoliosis underwent an extensive spinal correction surgery. During the operation, the surgical team failed to perform pre-op warming and did not adhere to the antibiotic re-dosing protocol as the procedure exceeded the expected duration. Following discharge, he experienced severe pain and developed a deep vein thrombosis, resulting in a readmission. The lack of compliance with the bundle protocols was a critical factor in his complications.

must_find_signals: Antibiotic redosing missed in long case

must_contain_phrases: lack of compliance with the bundle protocols

test_cases.description: Unplanned admission due to missing outcome risks.
test_cases.patient_payload: A 15-year-old female with a diagnosis of idiopathic scoliosis underwent surgery to correct her curvature. Post-operatively, she experienced significant pain that was not adequately controlled despite increasing analgesic requirements. A neurovascular exam was not documented pre-op, and her perfusion status was described only as 'normal' in the post-op notes. She was readmitted on day 10 with severe pain and suspicion of infection; however, no signs of neurological deficits or compartment syndrome were assessed. The lack of timely assessments may have contributed to her unplanned admission and return to operating room.

must_find_signals: significant pain that was not adequately controlled
neurovascular exam was not documented pre-op

test_cases.description: Unplanned admission due to missing readmission risks.
test_cases.patient_payload: A 16-year-old male with adolescent idiopathic scoliosis underwent spinal fusion surgery. Post-operative discharge instructions were unclear, leading to inadequate follow-up care. He returned to the ER within two weeks with uncontrolled pain and a possible surgical site infection. Upon reevaluation, it was discovered that antibiotic prophylaxis was not documented within the required timeframe, and the discharge instructions lacked details regarding signs of infection. This gap in communication and follow-up planning ultimately led to his unplanned admission for further treatment.

must_find_signals: uncontrolled pain and a possible surgical site infection
antibiotic prophylaxis was not documented within the required timeframe

test_cases.description: SSI prevention bundle documentation ambiguity in AIS fusion.
test_cases.patient_payload: A 15-year-old female with adolescent idiopathic scoliosis underwent spinal fusion surgery. On review, it was noted that the full surgical site infection (SSI) prevention bundle was not documented. The preoperative checklist failed to indicate the use of chlorhexidine prep and antibiotic prophylaxis was administered over 60 minutes prior to incision. Post-operatively, the patient developed a wound infection requiring readmission within 30 days. The lack of documentation and adherence to the SSI prevention bundle raises concerns about potential preventability of this complication.

must_find_signals: full surgical site infection (SSI) prevention bundle was not documented
chlorhexidine prep and antibiotic prophylaxis was administered over 60 minutes
lack of documentation and adherence to the SSI prevention bundle raises concerns

test_cases.description: Readmission reason categorization ambiguity post AIS surgery.
test_cases.patient_payload: A 17-year-old male with adolescent idiopathic scoliosis underwent corrective surgery. He was readmitted within 30 days due to severe abdominal pain and nausea. Upon review, the reason for readmission was not clearly categorized; it was initially thought to be related to a gastrointestinal complication but further evaluation suggested it may also be linked to inadequate pain control. The documentation lacked clarity on the exact cause, highlighting a gap in categorizing readmission reasons effectively.

must_find_signals: reason for readmission was not clearly categorized
gap in categorizing readmission reasons effectively

must_contain_phrases: initially thought to be related to a gastrointestinal complication

test_cases.description: Analysis of unplanned return to OR documentation.
test_cases.patient_payload: A 16-year-old female with adolescent idiopathic scoliosis underwent posterior spinal fusion. Postoperative day 3, she returned to the OR due to hardware failure, but the documentation was unclear whether it was planned or unplanned. The surgical team noted 'return to OR' but failed to specify the nature of the return. Further review indicated inadequate preoperative assessments and a lack of clear communication regarding the expectation for hardware integrity. This ambiguity in the documentation raises concerns over prevention strategies and the effectiveness of discharge planning.

must_find_signals: return to OR due to hardware failure
documentation was unclear whether it was planned or unplanned

test_cases.description: Assessment of discharge instructions and follow-up documentation.
test_cases.patient_payload: An 18-year-old male with adolescent idiopathic scoliosis was discharged post-surgery after a successful spinal fusion. However, upon review, it was discovered that the discharge instructions were not clearly documented, leading to confusion regarding follow-up appointments. The patient presented to the emergency department with uncontrolled pain and was readmitted due to a surgical site infection. The lack of clear discharge instructions and follow-up plans could have contributed to the readmission, highlighting a vital gap in patient education and continuity of care.

must_find_signals: discharge instructions were not clearly documented

test_cases.description: Documented infection risk management in a patient with idiopathic scoliosis.
test_cases.patient_payload: A 15-year-old female with a diagnosis of idiopathic scoliosis underwent posterior spinal fusion. Preoperative antibiotic prophylaxis was administered within 60 minutes of incision, and appropriate antibiotic selection was documented. The surgical site was stained with chlorhexidine prep, and no signs of infection were observed at the surgical site postoperatively. Neurovascular exams were conducted pre-op and post-op, confirming perfusion status was pink and warm. The patient was discharged with clear instructions for wound care, and follow-up appointments were scheduled to monitor recovery. No infection risks were identified during the perioperative period.

must_find_signals: Antibiotic prophylaxis was administered within 60 minutes of incision
Neurovascular exams were conducted pre-op and post-op
No signs of infection were observed at the surgical site postoperatively

Perfusion status was pink and warm

test_cases.description: Verified compliance with surgical bundle requirements for a scoliosis patient.
test_cases.patient_payload: A 14-year-old male diagnosed with idiopathic scoliosis was scheduled for corrective surgery. Bundle compliance was thoroughly documented, including pre-op warming and appropriate antibiotic redosing during surgery due to prolonged operative time. The surgical team confirmed the use of chlorhexidine prep, and post-op dressing protocol was followed without deviation. The patient received DVT prophylaxis as indicated, and the surgical timeout was effectively completed. Clear discharge instructions were provided, including signs of complications to monitor at home. No issues related to bundle compliance were noted during the perioperative phase.

must_find_signals: Pre-op warming and appropriate antibiotic redosing

must_contain_phrases: No issues related to bundle compliance were noted
Post-op dressing protocol was followed without deviation

test_cases.description: Patient experienced unplanned admission due to infection after scoliosis surgery.
test_cases.patient_payload: A 15-year-old female with idiopathic scoliosis underwent spinal fusion surgery. Post-operatively, she was discharged with clear instructions. However, she returned to the hospital 10 days later with increasing fever and wound drainage. The surgical site infection (SSI) was documented, and her antibiotic prophylaxis was not given within 60 minutes prior to incision, indicating a gap in compliance. She also exhibited pallor and delayed capillary refill, raising concerns for underlying infection. The documentation lacked precise details on her neurovascular status pre-operatively and post-operatively, suggesting missed checks. Recommendations include ensuring timely antibiotic administration and thorough discharge education to prevent future complications.

Documentation indicated that his pain was out of proportion to injury, and analgesic requirements increased significantly post-discharge. A neurovascular examination was not documented post-operatively, which could have highlighted the need for closer monitoring. The lack of a sufficient bowel regimen contributed to gastrointestinal complications, underscoring the need for better pain management and follow-up care protocols. To prevent similar readmissions, its vital to ensure comprehensive discharge instructions and pain control strategies.

test_cases.description: Clear documentation of outcome risks after scoliosis surgery.
test_cases.patient_payload: A 15-year-old female underwent posterior spinal fusion for idiopathic scoliosis. Post-surgery, she exhibited signs of infection with increasing wound erythema and discharge. The neurovascular exam documented post-op showed warm perfusion and normal sensation. However, the surgical site infection (SSI) risk was not adequately addressed as antibiotic prophylaxis was given 90 minutes after incision. The patient required unplanned admission for IV antibiotics and wound care, highlighting the need for improved antibiotic timing and infection monitoring.

must_find_signals: surgical site infection (SSI) risk was not adequately addressed

test_cases.description: Clear documentation of readmission risks after scoliosis surgery.
test_cases.patient_payload: A 17-year-old male patient was discharged after an anterior spinal fusion for adolescent idiopathic scoliosis. Post-operative, he presented with uncontrolled pain and nausea, leading to an unplanned admission due to GI complications. The discharge instructions were vague regarding pain management and bowel regimen, contributing to the readmission. The patient also exhibited signs of ileus and required further evaluation and treatment to manage his symptoms effectively, indicating a need for better discharge education and follow-up planning.

test_cases.description: Unplanned admission due to infection risks not addressed preoperatively.
test_cases.patient_payload: A 15-year-old female with adolescent idiopathic scoliosis underwent posterior spinal fusion surgery. Postoperatively, she developed fever and increased pain at the surgical site. Upon review, it was noted that antibiotic prophylaxis was not administered within 60 minutes prior to incision, as required. Additionally, there was no documentation regarding the selection of antibiotics. These factors raised concerns for potential surgical site infection (SSI), leading to her unplanned admission 20 days post-surgery. The lack of proactive measures and documentation gaps were identified as contributing factors to her readmission.

must_find_signals: Antibiotic prophylaxis was not administered within 60 minutes prior to incision
no documentation regarding the selection of antibiotics

test_cases.description: Unplanned return to OR due to missing bundle compliance.
test_cases.patient_payload: A 17-year-old male underwent surgery for idiopathic scoliosis correction. Postoperatively, he exhibited worsening pain and was readmitted after 15 days with a hematoma requiring reoperation. Review of his surgical notes revealed that pre-op warming was not documented, and the antibiotic redosing was missed during the prolonged operative time. These oversights resulted in complications that could have been avoided through better adherence to the SSI prevention bundle. The combination of these compliance failures was significant in leading to his unplanned return to the OR.

must_find_signals: antibiotic redosing was missed during the prolonged operative time

test_cases.description: Unplanned readmission due to missing infection signals.
test_cases.patient_payload: A 16-year-old female patient with idiopathic scoliosis underwent posterior spinal fusion surgery. Post-operative notes indicated increasing pain and a temperature of 101F, but the neurovascular exam was not documented pre-op or post-op. No mention of perfusion status was made, leading to concerns about surgical site infection (SSI). The patient's family reported a high pain requirement with no clear discharge instructions, which could have contributed to her 30-day readmission for suspected infection.

test_cases.description: Unplanned readmission due to missing signals of uncontrolled pain.
test_cases.patient_payload: A 15-year-old male patient with idiopathic scoliosis was discharged after spinal surgery. On follow-up, he presented with severe abdominal pain and nausea. The surgical site was noted to be intact, but there were no documented assessments regarding gastrointestinal complications or pain control strategies. The lack of a bowel regimen was evident. This oversight led to an emergency admission for gastrointestinal obstruction, highlighting gaps in post-operative care and patient education.

must_find_signals: no documented assessments regarding gastrointestinal complications

test_cases.description: Assessment of SSI prevention bundle documentation for AIS fusion.
test_cases.patient_payload: A 15-year-old female underwent anterior spinal fusion for idiopathic scoliosis. Despite a well-planned operative procedure, there was a significant delay in administering the full SSI prevention bundle. The pre-operative checklist indicated that antibiotic prophylaxis was not documented within the required 60 minutes prior to incision. Post-operatively, the patient developed signs of infection, including wound erythema and drainage. A review of the surgical notes revealed no documentation of the neurovascular exam pre-op and post-op, which raises concerns about compliance with infection prevention protocols. This situation underscores the need for thorough documentation and adherence to the SSI prevention bundle to mitigate future complications.

must_find_signals: antibiotic prophylaxis was not documented within the required 60 minutes
no documentation of the neurovascular exam pre-op and post-op

test_cases.description: Categorization of readmission reason after AIS surgery.
test_cases.patient_payload: A 17-year-old male was readmitted within 30 days following his scoliosis surgery due to severe uncontrolled pain and signs pointing to a possible hardware failure. The initial discharge summary lacked clarity, failing to categorize the readmission reason as related to hardware issues, which complicates the determination of preventability. The patient reported increasing analgesic requirements and pain that was out of proportion to his recovery. A follow-up assessment noted palpable tenderness over the surgical site, suggesting a potential complication requiring early return to the OR. This case highlights the importance of clear documentation and categorization of readmission reasons to improve future surgical outcomes.

must_find_signals: uncontrolled pain and signs pointing to a possible hardware failure
pain that was out of proportion to his recovery

test_cases.description: Assessment of unplanned return to OR due to infection management.
test_cases.patient_payload: A 15-year-old female underwent surgery for idiopathic scoliosis but returned to the OR within 30 days due to surgical site infection (SSI). The infection was not documented in the initial post-op notes, raising concerns about the clarity of the return being planned versus unplanned. The patient had increasing pain and erythema at the site, which were signs of infection. A surgical pause was not performed, and the antibiotic timing was not documented properly, leading to potential preventability issues. This incident highlights the need for better documentation and adherence to infection control protocols.

must_contain_phrases: documented in the initial post-op notes

test_cases.description: Evaluation of discharge instructions and follow-up adherence.
test_cases.patient_payload: A 17-year-old male with idiopathic scoliosis had a successful surgical procedure but was readmitted within 30 days due to uncontrolled pain and gastrointestinal complications. Upon review, it was found that the discharge instructions were unclear and lacked specific follow-up appointment details. The neurovascular exam documentation was also deficient, missing the perfusion status description. This inadequacy in communication may have contributed to the patient's inability to manage his symptoms effectively at home, leading to his readmission.

test_cases.description: Conflicting wound assessment findings leading to readmission.
test_cases.patient_payload: A 15-year-old female underwent posterior spinal fusion for idiopathic scoliosis. On post-op day 10, her surgical site was assessed, showing signs of erythema and slight drainage. However, subsequent assessments indicated no erythema or drainage, leading to confusion among the care team. On day 20, she presented with fever and increased drainage, requiring readmission for suspected surgical site infection (SSI). The conflicting findings in the wound assessments raise concerns about the adequacy of documentation and communication among the team. Proper wound assessment protocols might prevent similar issues in the future.

must_find_signals: conflicting findings in the wound assessments

required_themes: Was there a standardized protocol for wound assessment?
How was communication handled among the care team?

test_cases.description: Readmission close to the 30-day boundary due to pain control issues.
test_cases.patient_payload: A 16-year-old male who had undergone surgery for idiopathic scoliosis returned to the hospital on post-op day 28 with uncontrolled pain and nausea. His discharge instructions indicated a pain management regimen, but the patient reported not receiving adequate follow-up support. The readmission occurred just two days before the 30-day mark, raising questions about the effectiveness of his post-operative pain control plan and the timing of follow-up appointments. A review of his discharge summary showed no specific recommendations for pain management adjustments, which could have prevented his readmission.

must_find_signals: discharge instructions indicated a pain management regimen
readmission occurred just two days before the 30-day mark

must_contain_phrases: effectiveness of his post-operative pain control plan

required_themes: What follow-up care was arranged post-discharge?
How can pain management plans be improved?

test_cases.description: Discharge instructions were unclear leading to complications.
test_cases.patient_payload: A 15-year-old female with adolescent idiopathic scoliosis underwent spinal fusion surgery. Upon discharge, the nursing staff provided verbal instructions but failed to document essential aspects regarding pain management and signs of infection. The patient returned to the emergency department within 25 days due to uncontrolled pain and a surgical site infection. The unclear discharge instructions contributed to the patient's inability to recognize early warning signs, leading to her readmission. A review revealed the importance of clear, written discharge instructions to prevent such complications in future cases.

required_themes: How can discharge instructions be improved?
What education was provided to the patient?

test_cases.description: New neurological findings observed post-surgery with no clear cause.
test_cases.patient_payload: A 17-year-old male patient underwent surgery for adolescent idiopathic scoliosis. Post-operatively, he developed new neurological findings, including weakness in the right hand and altered sensation. The etiology of these changes was unclear, raising concerns about possible nerve compression or surgical complications. Despite thorough imaging and evaluations, no definitive cause was found. The patient's condition prompted a return to the operating room for exploration to rule out hardware issues. This incident highlights the need for more vigilant monitoring and assessment of neurological status post-surgery to identify complications early.

must_contain_phrases: etiology of these changes was unclear
return to the operating room for exploration

required_themes: What monitoring protocols were in place post-operatively?

test_cases.description: Patient readmitted due to surgical site infection after scoliosis surgery.
test_cases.patient_payload: A 15-year-old female underwent posterior spinal fusion for idiopathic scoliosis. Despite the operation being performed, antibiotic prophylaxis was not documented within 60 minutes prior to incision, which raised concerns about infection risks. Post-operatively, the patient developed redness and drainage from the surgical site, indicating a potential surgical site infection (SSI). The surgeon was unavailable for follow-up due to scheduling conflicts, which delayed addressing the complications. With no clear documentation of the patient's perfusion status or neurovascular checks, the risk of further complications increased significantly. The lack of a proper antibiotic regimen and follow-up assessment highlighted gaps in perioperative care that could be prevented in future cases.

must_find_signals: Antibiotic prophylaxis not given within 60 min

must_contain_phrases: redness and drainage from the surgical site

test_cases.description: Patient readmitted due to hardware complications after scoliosis surgery.
test_cases.patient_payload: An 18-year-old male underwent an anterior/posterior spinal fusion for adolescent idiopathic scoliosis. The operative time extended significantly, but no documentation of antibiotic redosing was provided during the lengthy procedure. After discharge, the patient returned to the emergency department with severe back pain and signs of hardware failure. The documentation revealed that the pre-op warming and antibiotic prophylaxis protocols were not followed, contributing to the patient's complications. The surgeon's unavailability for a timely follow-up further complicated the patient's care. This situation illustrates the need for improved adherence to surgical bundles and thorough documentation to prevent hardware-related issues.

must_find_signals: Antibiotic redosing missed in long case

must_contain_phrases: severe back pain and signs of hardware failure

test_cases.description: Patient readmitted due to unmonitored infection post-surgery.
test_cases.patient_payload: A 15-year-old female patient underwent surgery for idiopathic scoliosis. She was discharged on postoperative day 2 without clear discharge instructions regarding wound care. On day 5 post-op, she presented to the ER with fever and increasing pain at the surgical site. The surgical site showed erythema and drainage, but no neurovascular exam was documented post-op. The absence of proper infection risk assessment led to an unplanned admission for surgical site infection management. The lack of clear follow-up instructions may have contributed to her readmission.

must_find_signals: surgical site showed erythema and drainage
no neurovascular exam was documented post-op
absence of proper infection risk assessment

test_cases.description: Patient readmitted due to uncontrolled pain and documentation gaps.
test_cases.patient_payload: A 16-year-old male patient had corrective surgery for his idiopathic scoliosis. Postoperative pain management was inadequate, leading to escalating pain levels not documented in the medical record. On day 4 after discharge, the patient returned to the hospital with severe pain and nausea, ultimately diagnosed with a possible GI complication related to inadequate analgesia and bowel regimen. The documentation did not capture the frequency of neurovascular checks, and there was no record of the pain assessment post-operatively, emphasizing the need for better perioperative pain management strategies.

must_find_signals: escalating pain levels not documented in the medical record
no record of the pain assessment post-operatively

must_contain_phrases: documentation did not capture the frequency of neurovascular checks

test_cases.description: Assessment of SSI prevention bundle documentation for AIS fusion.
test_cases.patient_payload: A 15-year-old female with adolescent idiopathic scoliosis underwent a spinal fusion procedure. Post-operatively, the patient developed a surgical site infection (SSI) after being discharged home. Upon review, it was found that the full SSI prevention bundle was not documented, raising concerns about the effectiveness of infection prevention strategies. Antibiotic prophylaxis was initiated but not within the recommended 60 minutes prior to incision. There was no documentation of pre-op warming or chlorhexidine prep. These oversights could have contributed to the infection and subsequent readmission. A thorough review of the surgical pause and timeout also revealed missing elements, indicating incomplete compliance with the prevention bundle.

must_find_signals: full SSI prevention bundle was not documented
antibiotic prophylaxis was initiated but not within the recommended 60 minutes
no documentation of pre-op warming or chlorhexidine prep

must_contain_phrases: incomplete compliance with the prevention bundle

test_cases.description: Categorization of reason for readmission after AIS surgery.
test_cases.patient_payload: A 17-year-old male patient was readmitted within 30 days post-adolescent idiopathic scoliosis surgery due to severe uncontrolled pain. Review of the case revealed that the source of pain was linked to hardware failure, specifically a broken rod. However, documentation lacked clarity categorizing the reason for readmission, leading to confusion about whether it was solely due to pain or if the hardware issue also contributed. The patient had increasing analgesic requirements and was experiencing pain out of proportion to his injury, which were significant safety signals. The lack of precise categorization could hinder targeted interventions to prevent future occurrences.

must_find_signals: hardware failure, specifically a broken rod
lack of clarity categorizing the reason for readmission

must_contain_phrases: pain out of proportion to his injury

test_cases.description: Patient returned to OR for complications after scoliosis surgery.
test_cases.patient_payload: A 15-year-old female underwent posterior spinal fusion for idiopathic scoliosis. Post-op, she developed significant pain and was found to have a hematoma that required surgical intervention. The return to the OR was documented as unplanned, but the clinical team noted that the original discharge instructions did not emphasize signs of hematoma formation. Further review revealed that the surgical pause/timeout was missing from the documentation, raising questions about the quality of discharge teaching and awareness of potential complications. This oversight could be linked to inadequate follow-up planning, as the follow-up appointment was scheduled for three weeks post-surgery, potentially delaying timely intervention for complications.

must_find_signals: return to the OR was documented as unplanned
original discharge instructions did not emphasize signs of hematoma formation
surgical pause/timeout was missing from the documentation

test_cases.description: Patient readmitted due to unclear discharge instructions.
test_cases.patient_payload: An 18-year-old male was discharged after scoliosis correction surgery but returned within a week due to uncontrolled pain and signs of superficial surgical site infection. The medical record showed that discharge instructions were provided verbally but lacked written documentation and clarity regarding pain management and signs of infection. A review of the case indicated that the patient did not receive adequate information on recognizing symptoms that might require immediate medical attention, leading to an unplanned readmission. The absence of a structured follow-up appointment plan contributed to his delayed response to these complications.

must_find_signals: discharge instructions were provided verbally but lacked written documentation
lack of clarity regarding pain management
absence of a structured follow-up appointment plan

test_cases.description: Patient presented with clear signs of infection post-surgery.
test_cases.patient_payload: A 14-year-old female with idiopathic scoliosis underwent spinal fusion surgery. Postoperatively, she developed a surgical site infection (SSI) evidenced by wound erythema and drainage. Antibiotic prophylaxis was administered within 60 minutes prior to incision, and appropriate antibiotics were selected. The surgical time was within acceptable limits, and there was no history of prior infection. However, documentation gaps were noted regarding the neurovascular exam post-op, which could have highlighted potential risks earlier. To prevent similar events, emphasis on thorough post-operative monitoring and documentation is essential.

must_find_signals: Antibiotic prophylaxis was administered within 60 minutes

test_cases.description: Patient's compliance with the surgical bundle was documented clearly.
test_cases.patient_payload: A 15-year-old male with idiopathic scoliosis underwent corrective surgery. The surgical team adhered to the bundle compliance checklist: pre-op warming was documented, chlorhexidine prep was applied, and DVT prophylaxis was administered. Antibiotics were redosed appropriately during the lengthy procedure, and excessive traffic in the OR was minimized. Despite these measures, the patient experienced significant postoperative pain and required increased analgesics. This highlights the need for better pain management strategies post-surgery to prevent readmission due to uncontrolled pain.

test_cases.description: Patient developed infection after scoliosis surgery.
test_cases.patient_payload: A 15-year-old female with idiopathic scoliosis underwent posterior spinal fusion. Post-operatively, she developed a surgical site infection (SSI) with increasing pain out of proportion to injury and had a fever. Antibiotic prophylaxis was not given within 60 minutes prior to incision, and the surgical pause was not documented. She was readmitted on day 10 with signs of infection confirmed by a positive culture. The neurovascular exam was not documented post-op, leading to inadequate monitoring of her recovery. Proper pre-op warming was not documented, contributing to the infection risk.

must_find_signals: Antibiotic prophylaxis was not given within 60 minutes prior to incision
neurovascular exam was not documented post-op

must_contain_phrases: pain out of proportion to injury

test_cases.description: Patient readmitted due to uncontrolled pain and GI complications.
test_cases.patient_payload: A 17-year-old male with idiopathic scoliosis underwent corrective surgery but was readmitted after 15 days due to uncontrolled pain and signs of gastrointestinal obstruction. He had an inadequate bowel regimen post-operation, leading to severe abdominal distension and vomiting. Documentation gaps included a lack of clear discharge instructions related to pain management and bowel care. He also experienced increasing analgesic requirement and had not been educated on signs of gastrointestinal complications before discharge. This oversight prompted his unplanned return to the OR for bowel decompression.

test_cases.description: Unplanned admission due to surgical site infection following idiopathic scoliosis surgery.
test_cases.patient_payload: A 15-year-old female, diagnosed with idiopathic scoliosis, underwent posterior spinal fusion surgery. Post-operatively, the patient exhibited increasing redness and drainage from the surgical site, indicating a possible infection. However, antibiotic prophylaxis was not documented as being administered within 60 minutes of incision, and the operative time exceeded 6 hours without redosing antibiotics. The discharge instructions were unclear regarding signs of infection, leading to a 10-day post-operative readmission for management of surgical site infection (SSI). The lack of pre-operative and post-operative neurovascular exams further complicated her case, as perfusion status was not documented, raising concerns about her care.

must_find_signals: Antibiotic prophylaxis not given within 60 min

test_cases.description: Unplanned return to OR due to missed compliance with surgical bundles after scoliosis surgery.
test_cases.patient_payload: A 17-year-old male with idiopathic scoliosis underwent corrective spinal surgery. Post-operation, the patient presented with uncontrolled pain and required multiple doses of analgesics. A review of the surgical notes revealed that pre-op warming was not documented, and the chlorhexidine prep was either not performed or not recorded. Additionally, the antibiotic redosing was missed during the prolonged operative time, leading to complications that necessitated a return to the OR for washout of suspected infection. The documentation lacked a proper surgical timeout, raising further concerns about the compliance with safety protocols.

must_find_signals: Antibiotic redosing missed in long case
